metadata.title: Post-synthetic modification of IRMOF-3 with an iminopalladacycle complex and its application as an effective heterogeneous catalyst in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction in H<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf>O/EtOH media at room temperature

Editor’s choice paper Post-synthetic modification of IRMOF-3 with an iminopalladacycle complex and its application as an effective heterogeneous catalyst in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction in H2O/EtOH media at room temperature Fatemeh Nouri Shahnaz Rostamizadeh ⁎ Mohammad Azad Department of Chemistry, K.N. Toosi University of Technology, P.O. Box 15787-4416, Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry K.N. Toosi University of Technology P.O. Box 15787 Tehran 4416 Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A novel iminopalladacycle complex was successfully immobilized onto a metal–organic framework (MOF) through post-synthetic modification of IRMOF-3. Initially, the IRMOF-3 was modified with benzaldehyde to achieve a Schiff-base moiety in the pores of IRMOF-3 (IRMOF-3-BI) which could anchor the palladium by the addition of palladium acetate (IRMOF-3-BI-Pd). The catalyst was fully characterized by using a variety of methods such as attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX), inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Also, the structural unities of MOFs have been confirmed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis. Moreover, the prepared catalyst has shown excellent turnover frequencies as a heterogonous catalyst in the Suzuki C-C coupling reaction for aryl iodides, bromides and chlorides in H2O/EtOH media at room temperature. Additionally, the catalyst can be easily isolated from the reaction mixture and recycled for five sequential runs without incredible decrease in catalytic efficiency. Keywords Metal-organic framework IRMOF-3 Palladacycle Suzuki-Miyaura reaction Room temperature 1 Introduction Traditional Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions, for instance, Suzuki-Miyaura have found great importance as a common way to prepare biaryl structures in organic synthesis and industrial processes [1], which are accomplished typically by using palladium salts moieties or organometallic palladium complexes including phosphine ligands [2]. Among the Pd-catalysts, palladacycles are one of the most important and effective kind of palladium complexes to promote carbon–carbon coupling reactions [3]. Although palladacycle catalytic systems are known to exhibit better activity than other palladium systems [4], but they suffer from problems associated to their instability and without the use of a stabilizer support, are susceptible to degradation and lose their catalytic activity after just one cycle, especially in aqueous media and bring about considerations of economic and environmental aspects [5]. Inversely, heterogeneous palladacycle catalysts can be separated from the reaction mixture and partly reused. Therefore, the use of a suitable stabilizer or support for palladacycle catalytic systems is generally effective. Hence, in recent years, a number of solid materials including MCM-41, SiO2, polystyrene-divinylbenzene polymer [6], polystyrene [7], polyvinylpyridine (PVP) [8], chitosan [9], Fe3O4 nanoparticles [10] and etc. have been used as support for palladacycles in carbon–carbon coupling reactions. However, there are still some restrictions regarding the catalytic efficiency, stability and reusability. Consequently, exploration of the new heterogeneous palladacycle catalysts for cross-coupling reactions has been of considerable interest, especially in the case of using aryl chlorides. In recent years, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have found much attention as a new class of nanoporous solid materials mostly because of their possibility to design and functionalize. MOFs are novel crystalline hybrid materials composed of metal ions or metal clusters coordinated by polydentate organic ligands via self-assembly process. As opposed to conventional porous materials, MOFs possess the reticular structures with high specific surface areas, tunable pore sizes, the possibility to functionalize and ability to recognize optionally small to large molecules on the basis of the structure [11]. Thus, they are applying in reversible gas storage, sensing, biomedical imaging, drug delivery and catalysis [12]. In the case of heterogeneous catalytic aspect, post-synthetic modification and immobilization of functional sites (coordinately unsaturated metal centers) within MOFs is very important [13]. In recent years, various functional groups and organometallic moieties have been anchored onto different MOFs [14]. Among the different MOFs, IRMOF-3 is a famous MOF having a cubic framework which assembled from Zn(NO3)2 and 2-aminoterphtalic acid [15]. Therefore, there are free amine functional groups which are not joined to tetragonal ZnO4 as nodes, and provide a route to post-synthetic modification of IRMOF-3 with various organometallic groups. In this context, Ahn et al. have immobilized the acetylacetonate magnesium (II) complex onto IRMOF-3 and applied it as a heterogeneous catalyst [16]. Also, Xin and his coworkers have functionalized IRMOF-3 with 2-hyroxybenzaldehyde which anchored Au+3/Au0 species [17]. IRMOF-3 has also been modified with pyridine-2-carbaldehyde by Koner and gave a porous support with bidentate Schiff base moiety which anchored PdCl2 and indicates good catalytic activity in Suzuki cross-coupling reaction [18]. Wang et al. have reported the modification of IRMOF-3 with a copper-iminopyridine complex as well [19]. Additionally, IRMOF-3 has been modified with some ligands such as chloroacetic acid, glyoxylic acid, diethylmalonate and methyl vinyl ketone and it has been used to coordinate Eu3+ and Nd3+ cations [20]. Therefore, as is observed, various functional groups and organometallic moieties have been anchored onto IRMOF-3, but to the extent of our knowledge, there is no report dealing with modification of MOFs with a palladacycle. Hence, in continuation of our interest in preparing heterogeneous catalysts [21], we are intending to apply IRMOF-3 as host matrices to support the iminopalladacycle with the hope to lead to the stability and high efficiency of palladcycle catalyst for catalyzing the CC coupling reaction even for the less reactive aryl chlorides. As a result, for the first time, we report the preparation of a new and stable IRMOF-3 supported iminopalladacycle catalyst through post-synthetic modification strategy and present its excellent catalytic efficiency in Suzuki-Miyaura reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and instruments All chemical materials were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Fulka and Merck companies. A Thermo Scientific Nicolet 380 FT-IR spectrometer was applied for ATR-FTIR spectrometry. The Suzuki products in Table 3 were identified by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy using a Bruker Avance spectrometer at 300 and 75MHz, respectively and the spectra were provided with electronic supplementary information (ESI). The metal content was determined through inductively coupled plasma technique by the Varian Vista-MPX system. TGA curve was recorded by the NETZSCH STA 409 PC system under nitrogen atmosphere. A scanning electron microscope (Vega TESCAN model) equipped with energy dispersive X-ray was applied for energy dispersive X-ray analysis and determination of the structural morphology of IRMOF-3. X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out using a PHILIPS X-ray diffractometer system (PW1800-Model). The CHN analysis was performed by a 2400 series II elemental analyzer. An XR3E2, 8025-BesTec-Model twin anode X-ray source system was used for X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The nitrogen sorption curves was recorded by [5.0.0.3] Belsorp, BEL Japan, INC. system for determination of specific surface area of the nanostructures. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst 2.2.1 Preparation of IRMOF-3 (1), [Zn4O(ATA)3] (ATA=2-amino terephthalate). IRMOF-3 was prepared according to the method previously reported in the literature with a slight alteration [22]. Thus, 0.75g 2-aminoterphtalic acid Eq. (1) and 3.00g Zn(NO3)2·4H2O Eq. (3) were dissolved in 50mL DMF in a sealed reaction bottle. Then it was heated at 110°C in an oil bath. After 18h, the amber brown fine cubic crystals of IRMOF-3 were produced and stick on the wall of dish. The hot mother liquor was decanted and the resulting solid was washed with DMF several times and finally with chloroform. The dried solid was dispersed in fresh chloroform every 12h for tree times. Then it was dried at 100°C under vacuum conditions and elemental analysis was applied on the solid; found: C 35.3%, H 1.8%, N 5.21%; calculated for Zn4O(ATA)3: C 35.36%, H 1.85%, N 5.17%. 2.2.2 Preparation of IRMOF-3-BI (2), [Zn4O(ATA)2.67(BITA)0.33] (BITA=2-benzyl-imine terephthalate) In a round bottom flask, 0.318g benzaldehyde was dissolved in 20mL acetonitrile. Then, 0.640g IRMOF-3 was added to it. The resulting mixture was stirred for one day at room temperature. The crème-coloured product was centrifuged and washed with ethanol several times and dried under vacuum condition. Then, elemental analysis was applied on the solid; found: C 37.39%, H 1.89%, N 5.1%; calculated for Zn4O(ATA)2.67(BITA)0.33 (according to 11% functionalized NH2 group): C 37.43%, H 1.93%, N 4.98%. 2.2.3 Preparation of IRMOF-3-BI-Pd (3), [Zn4O(ATA)3−x(BITA-Pd-OAc)x] 0.130g of the prepared IRMOF-3-BI was poured in a round bottom flask containing 15mL dichloromethane and then 0.010g Pd(OAc)2 was added to it. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 18h. Then, the final solid was centrifuged and thoroughly washed with chloroform and dichloromethane several times and allowed to dry under vacuum condition. According to the inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP), the amount of Pd incorporated in the catalyst was 3.48%wt which indicated 91% complexion. Then, elemental analysis was applied on the solid; found: C 36.4%, H 1.9%, N 4.55%; calculated for Zn4O(ATA)2.67(BITA)0.03 (BITA-Pd-OAc)0.30 (according to 11% functionalized NH2 group and 91% incorporated palladium): C 36.26%, H 1.95%, N 4.61%. 2.3 General procedure for Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction of aryl halides with olefins In a 25mL round bottom flask containing 1mmol aryl halide, 1.1mmol boronic acid derivatives, 1mmolK2CO3 and 0.002g (6.5×10−2 mol%) catalyst (3), 3mL H2O/EtOH mixture in 1:1 ratio was added as solvent. Then the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20–60min. The reaction was monitored by TLC (thin layer chromatography). After completion of the reaction, the residue was filtrated and organic phase extracted with dichloromethane. Then, solvent was removed under vacuum conditions. Finally, the Suzuki product was recrystallized by EtOH and water (92–98% in yield). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst All steps of the preparation of catalyst have been outlined in Scheme 1 . The presence of all the elements in the prepared compounds was confirmed by CHN analysis, ICP (Section 2.2) and EDX analysis (Fig. 1 ). In order to identify all functional groups in the resulting materials, IR spectroscopy was performed using attenuated total reflectance technique (ATR) after each step of the preparation of catalyst (Fig. 2 ). A broad peak appeared in the range between 3500 and 3300cm−1 was clearly related to the amine group in IRMOF-3. Also, a strong peak appeared at 1563cm−1 was related to the bending vibration of the amine group. The appearance of a new band at 1654cm−1 in IR spectrum of IRMOF-3-BI obviously indicated the formation of CN bond and well modification of IRMOF-3 framework (according to the 11% functionalization of −NH2 group in Section 2.2.2). Also, in IR spectrum of IRMOF-3-BI-Pd, the band related to CN bond was shifted into lower frequency 1616cm−1, which revealed that the coordination of imine group with palladium and the formation of iminopalladacycle. Also, a new small absorption band was appeared at 1420cm−1, which could be attributed to the CO stretching vibration of acetate bound to palladium. Moreover, the peaks related to the carboxylate groups were seen at around 1430–1380cm−1 in all three steps. Moreover, in order to confirm the crystalline structure of the prepared IRMOF-3, X-ray diffraction analysis was performed (Fig. 3 ). The resulting XRD pattern obviously showed all the peaks related to IRMOF-3 according to the literature [23]. Correspondingly, the unities of the frameworks were also verified for IRMOF-3-BI and IRMOF-3-BI-Pd, in which all the peaks were unaltered. As a result, the crystalline structure of IRMOF-3 has been maintained after functionalization and palladation. Additionally, the structural morphology of IRMOF-3 was investigated by scanning electron microscopy technique (Fig. 4 ). According to the Figure, the prepared IRMOF-3 has a smooth cubic crystalline microstructure with uniform size nearly 30μm. The porous properties of prepared IRMOF-3 and IRMOF-3-BI-Pd catalyst, were also determined by nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis (Fig. 5 ). As is clear, the resulting plots indicated an intermediate mode between type II and type IV isotherms, which were associated to the microporus and mesoporous materials according to the IUPAC classification [24]. The small hystersis loops observed in isotherms could be assigned to the aggregation of crystals and the mesoporous areas. BET surface areas and average pore diameter were achieved from isotherms and pore volumes were determined using BJH method (Table 1 ). As shown in Table, the prepared IRMOF-3 and IRMOF-3-BI-Pd catalyst (3) had high surface areas, which were similar to the other MOFs systems [25]. A decrease in BET surface area and pore volume was observed after modification of IRMOF-3, which was related to the formation of schiff base moieties and the formation of IRMOF-3-BI-Pd. Additionally, the thermal stability of the catalyst (3) was measured using thermogravimetric-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) (Fig. 6 ). As is clear from the resulting curve, about 5% mass loss was observed at above 100°C, which was related to the dehydration and desolvation processes. Also, another fast weigh loss which occurred at above 300°C could be assigned to some organic parts of the catalyst. The fastest and highest decrease in mass was observed around 400–500°C, which is attributed to the degradation of metal-organic framework. As a result, the catalyst (3) was highly stable for organic processes even at high temperatures. The binding energy of palladium incorporated into iminopalldacyle complex of catalyst (3) was determined using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy method (Fig. 7 ). The results revealed the values at 342.85eV and 348.30eV for 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 core-levels of Pd(II), respectively, which were in good agreement with values of the other imine-based palladium complexes [26]. 3.2 Catalytic function of IRMOF-3-BI-Pd (3) in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction In order to study the efficiency of the IRMOF-3-BI-Pd catalyst, it was tested in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction. Therefore, the reaction conditions were first optimized. The optimization was carried out for the reaction of 4-bromobenzonitrile (1mmol) with phenylboronic acid (1.1mmol) in the presence of IRMOF-3-BI-Pd catalyst (3) under various conditions. In this regard, different solvents and bases were applied in the presence of the different amounts of catalyst at various temperatures. The results are summarized in Table 2 . As shown in Table, the reaction proceeded slowly in DMF or toluene, while it became faster in ethanol (entries 5–10) and was accelerated to 30min in time by adding H2O (entries 5–8). By the comparison of the results, the 1:1 ratio of H2O/EtOH mixture was selected as the reaction solvent (entry 7). Moreover, various bases including both organic and inorganic bases were used. The results clearly revealed that inorganic bases were more effective to promote the reaction and among them, K2CO3 was the most efficient one. It is worth mentioning that the reaction did not proceed in the absence of base (entry 14). Also, the comparison of turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) of different mounts of catalyst (entries 6–8) indicated that (6.5×10−2 mol%) of IRMOF-3-BI-Pd catalyst results in the highest TOF (entry 7). In order to show the efficiency of the prepared catalyst, a blank reaction was also performed without catalyst, in which no product was observed (entry 13). A control reaction was performed with Pd(OAc)2 alone as well (entry 15), which in addition to low yield, all the palladium was leached into the reaction solution (palladium black), while it did not occurred in the presence of catalyst (3) (Section 3.3). The reaction was also accomplished at various temperatures. However, it proceeded very fast at room temperature. As a result, the reaction was carried out in an optimized conditions including H2O/EtOH mixture as solvent and K2CO3 as base in the presence of 6.5×10−2 mol% palladium from IRMOF-3-BI-Pd catalyst (3) at room temperature (entry 7). The optimized condition was then effectively generalized for the reaction of various aryl iodides, bromides and chlorides with boronic acid derivatives and all the different Suzuki-Miyaura products were successfully synthesized in short reaction times with excellent yields (Table 3 ). Finally, in order to show the efficiency of the prepared catalyst, we provided a table in which TONs and TOFs values were compared for the various supported palladium catalysts reported in the literature (Table 4 ). As is cear from table, the IRMOF-3-BI-Pd (3) catalyst showed the highest efficiency to catalyze the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction among the other palladium catalytic systems. 3.3 Reusability of the catalyst Reusability is one of the most significant aspects of a valuable heterogeneous catalyst, mainly from economical and industrial standpoints and shows the chemical stability and efficiency of the catalyst as well. Therefore, we are intending to investigate the reusability of the catalyst by running the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction for 4-bromobenzonitrile and phenylboronic acid under optimized conditions in two types of solvents applied in Table 2 (entries 7, 9). In the case of using H2O/EtOH as solvent, the reactions were stopped after 30min and for the case of EtOH after 60min. At the end of each run, the catalyst was isolated by centrifuging and thoroughly washed with water and ethanol and dried at 80°C. Then it was applied for subsequent cycle. According to the results, the catalyst effectively carried out the reactions up to 5 cycles with high yields in the restricted times and its efficiency were not significantly decreased yet after 5 runs (Fig. 8 ). Also, in order to determine the amount of leached palladium into the solution, the catalyst was firstly separated from the reaction by centrifuging and then ICP analysis was performed on the solution. The aforesaid examination was accomplished after the first and fifth cycles for both of conditions. According to the results, the amounts of leached palladium during the first reaction were only 5.3×10−5 wt% (0.53ppm) and 6.2×10−5 wt% (0.62ppm) for H2O/EtOH and EtOH, respectively. Also, 0.32wt% and 0.46wt% of total palladium were released after fifth runs correspondingly. Thus, the results of leaching test indicated that the prepared IRMOF-3-BI-Pd catalyst (3) is a highly stable and reusable heterogeneous catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have successfully designed and synthesized a new modified IRMOF-3 with an iminopalladacycle moiety and presented its activity as a heterogeneous palladium catalyst in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction. This catalyst was capable of promoting the reaction of aryl iodide, bromides and even aryl chlorides with different boronic acids in short reaction times with excellent yields under a green and benign condition. Moreover, the catalyst could be recovered and recycled for five successive runs without substantial diminution in yields. Therefore, this approach opens a promising outlook for modification of metal-organic frameworks in catalytic fields and provides an economical and environmentally synthetic route into cross-coupling reactions and therefore makes the IRMOF-3-BI-Pd catalyst appropriate for green catalytic aspects. Acknowledgements We gratefully appreciate the Research Council of K.N. Toosi University of Technology for assisting this research. coredata.dc:description: A novel iminopalladacycle complex was successfully immobilized onto a metal–organic framework (MOF) through post-synthetic modification of IRMOF-3. Initially, the IRMOF-3 was modified with benzaldehyde to achieve a Schiff-base moiety in the pores of IRMOF-3 (IRMOF-3-BI) which could anchor the palladium by the addition of palladium acetate (IRMOF-3-BI-Pd). The catalyst was fully characterized by using a variety of methods such as attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX), inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Also, the structural unities of MOFs have been confirmed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis. Moreover, the prepared catalyst has shown excellent turnover frequencies as a heterogonous catalyst in the Suzuki C-C coupling reaction for aryl iodides, bromides and chlorides in H2O/EtOH media at room temperature. Additionally, the catalyst can be easily isolated from the reaction mixture and recycled for five sequential runs without incredible decrease in catalytic efficiency.
coredata.dc:title: Post-synthetic modification of IRMOF-3 with an iminopalladacycle complex and its application as an effective heterogeneous catalyst in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction in H2O/EtOH media at room temperature
